utterances: What of the current day student there, Mr. President?
How hard is it to really make them understand the times?
Well, it's difficult, candidly.
This generation is not what I would call the history conscious generation.
Although we do have some students who are very sensitive to the past and understand its implications to the future.

When we have the memorial on campus, there can be upwards of a couple of hundred students who are involved in the walk and in the candlelight commemoration, but, you know, that's part of our task as educators, candidly, to connect what's happened in the past with what needs to happen and will happen in the future.
What of the idea of cultivating a relationship between students and police?
Obviously, it's a different day, different tone, different tenor, and relationships across the board in this country are better usually with the university police and students.
But is there a conscious effort to make sure that that relationship is fostered with a friendly atmosphere?
Well, you know, it's a different time and a different circumstance.
We don't have any issues now between city police and our students.
Campus police serve a different type of role.
You know, they're as much educators and learners as anyone else on campus, and we expect them to play that role.
I thought you were going to ask another question, so let me go ahead and answer it anyway.
You know, we do have relationships with the Kent State folks that have come out of this.
And they commemorate Jackson State, as well as Kent State, each and every year, you know, to remember what happened, and we do the same thing.
What would you like to see come out of this as we look back at those times?
Certainly a lesson about, you know, what can happen if there is a lack of understanding on any level.

You know, most of what happened in the '70s happened at least at Jackson State because there was a street that ran through campus that white citizens drove through in order to get to work and racial epithets went back and forth between the students and the residents of Jackson.

It was a little thing like that that ended up in two deaths, and I guess the lesson to be learned is that little things can end up in very bad ways if we're not conscious each and every moment of what we do and why and how we do it.
Ronald Mason Jr., president of Jackson State University in Jackson, Mississippi.
Thanks for joining us today.
Thank you, Ed.
Appreciate it.
This is NPR News.
From NPR News, this is WEEKEND EDITION.
I'm Liane Hansen.
And joining us is puzzlemaster Will Shortz.
Hi, Will.
Hi, Liane.
Welcome back from Jamaica.
Thanks a lot.
How was the wedding?
The wedding was informal and very nice.
I got to go around the island a little bit.
We spent a day in Ocho Rios, which I had previously known only from crosswords.
(Soundbite of laughter)
You finally get to see the place that the word defines, right?
That's right.
Glad you're back in New York.
So remind us of that challenge you gave us last week.
Yes.
I said take the phrase, Yeshiva Center, which is a place of Jewish studies, rearrange these 13 letters to name a classic movie.
And what movie is it?
Well, before I tell you answer, I wanted to mention an NPR listener's Web site.
He made 13 Scrabble tiles with these letters and he formed funny answers with them and then photographed them.
And like - answers like Try Heaven's Ice and I've Cheery Ants.
And if you do a Web search on puzzle me this plus NPR, you can find it.
Anyway, the correct answer is ""Seven Year Itch,"" with Marilyn Monroe.
You bet - and Tom Ewell.
Well, we had over 800 entries from people who solved this puzzle.
And our randomly selected winner is Lauren Zentz from Tucson, Arizona.
Hi, Lauren.
Hello, Liane and Will.
Hi.
What do you there in Tucson?
I'm in the Department of Language, Reading and Culture, working on my doctorate.
Oh, very nice.
Well done.
Oh, a language expert.
Boy, I think I'm going to able to use you as a team player today, huh?
Well, it's funny.
Because I was already talking to my parents about next year, 4th of July, and saying how perfect it would be to be on the rooftop deck watching the fireworks over the harbor.
You never know, it might be fate.
It's a scenario playing out in cities across the country, and it's not just because the federal homebuyer's tax credit is gone, says John Gollinger.
Because you can never get in front of the consumer in a declining market.
It's a constant chase.
It's insidious.
Gollinger runs Accelerated Marketing Strategies, the company behind the auction.
He says the event dissolves the disconnect between what buyers are willing to pay and what sellers are willing to accept.
When you make a critical mass of sales occur, driven by the consumer in a very competitive environment, it's gonna free up the market.
It's going to actually break the logjam that's occurring right now in this market.
Gollinger's team sold $12 million of real estate in a little over an hour.
The highest price for a townhome: $956,000.
The lowest: 516,000.
But are auctions a new trend?
If you get to the point where auction becomes a common occurrence, it loses a lot of its punch.
Lewis Goodkin is a real estate analyst based in Miami.
He says auctions can work in cities, where the supply of new homes is limited.
But in places like Miami, or Las Vegas, where there are thousands of available homes...
The more distressed the market is, the more auctions that you have, the more, if you will, bargain selling that you see going on conventionally - that makes a difficult environment for auctions.
Goodkin says, like in any transaction, there are winners and losers.
In Baltimore, Tracy Feliciani came out on the losing end.
She got outbid by a father buying a townhouse for his 24-year-old daughter.
But Feliciani says she won't give up on the possibility of waterfront living.
There are a couple other units in the complex that I'm still interested in, so it will be good to go back and think about them and take a look at them and see what happens after that.
But it was a good experience.
For NPR News, I'm Cathy Duchamp.
Election officials in Alaska are up against the clock.
They have until this Friday to translate all of the state's election materials into two indigenous languages.
A U.S.
District Court judge ruled that the state had violated the Voting Rights Act by not providing the translations into the languages of Yup'ik and Gwich'in.
KUAC's Emily Schwing has the story.
The court ruling applies to everything from poll workers' buttons that read Can I help?
- To candidates' statements to the ballots themselves.
There are four regional election pamphlets totaling more than 600 pages.
Some will be translated into the Yup'ik language.
Allan Hayton is translating the material into the Gwich'in language.
Some of it is very technical language, legal jargon.
And it's - can be difficult to translate into our language.
Gwich'in is entirely unrelated to European languages and its vocabulary is vast.
Here's Hayton's translation of this sentence - the Alaska Departments of Natural Resources and Law...
(Speaking Gwich'in).
...Have prepared the following statement of cost to the state of Alaska.
(Speaking Gwich'in).
